9495471.review:
I would return this game if I could.  For such a small game, it's hard to imagine the developers possibly finding any /more/ ways they could screw it up and render it unplayable.

Expect ear-splittingly loud audio when you first start the game.  Setting volume at 1/10 makes it bearable, but expect a repeat performance every time you come back.  If you're unlucky like me, you won't even be able to play anyway, because the game speed is up by at least an order of magnitude - you won't even be able to navigate the menus.  If you get that fixed, still expect random timing glitches based on whether you have vsync on.

But those are all bugs, and one presumes that if the developers have any shred of decency or respect for their consumers, they'll at least fix those.  No the real deal-breaker is the controls.

Control mappings are backwards (jump/confirm swapped with shoot/cancel) and can't even be customized.  Countless side-scrollers that have come before have trained us to expect a competent layout that puts your most spammed inputs (movement) closest to the base of the thumb, and conversely your limited use controls further away.  But no, Towerfall went way out of its way to make it as hard as possible not to hit the wrong button /constantly/.  This and this alone renders the game an unplayable exercise in frustration just with the inputs.  The actual gameplay doesn't even factor in.

Don't expect to be able to pick up their slack either.  Mapping controller keys to other controller keys is pretty much impossible or just not worth the exhorbitant effort depending on what hardware you have, and just mapping to keyboard keys won't work either - the game will then read both.

I feel like an incredible sucker for buying this game on two steam accounts before I actually tried it - never even considered it could be this messed up, not when the reviews are so positive and only focus on gameplay and the lack of online play.  This wouldn't pass muster for a PC game in the 90s and would make a sub-par free flash game today.

When did developers lose all respect for their customers?  We're humans, not programmable money machines.  Software conforms to us, not the other way around.  To not even bother allowing any way to remap keys - even if the default mapping weren't retarded - is just a slap in the face.  I cannot imagine in what world falling short on even this baseline effort could possibly be considered acceptable and worthy of my money.  I want mine back, and barring that, you can at least be sure the developers responsible for this game will never swindle a penny from me ever again.

The mechanics of the game are very simple; however, this game is far from easy. This is a twitch shooter where you have to constantly be aware of your surroundings, the amount of ammunition you have, and the abilities of each monster. As someone who loves couch cooperative games and owns a fairly large collection, I am happy to say that Towerfall is one of the best. Towerfall has that "pixel-perfect" movement that makes simply running around and mastering each map a joy. The level of polish present far surpasses that of many other indie games and the inclusion of quest mode makes this release substantially more complete than the OUYA version.

Compared to the recently released Samurai Gunn, I would say that Towerfall offers more complexity and a higher skill cap, not to mention more content and customization. Among my friends Towerfall is already the clear favorite. However even without multiplayer, I have played 5+ hours of singleplayer and still have many more trials and secrets to unlock. If you enjoy classic arcade games and are without nearby gaming friends, I would still highly reccommend purchasing Towerfall. Improving upon times in Trials mode and beating High Scores in Quest Mode offer an endless challenge, while simply clearing all the levels on diamond and hardcore will take most people atleast 8 hours!

That being said, this game truly shines when you and three of your buddies gather around the same television. With thousands of possible game variants, easy to learn but hard to master gameplay, and short enjoyable rounds I don't see myself playing any other game with my friends for a long time.

9435385.review:
TowerFall Ascension is not for the faint-hearted. It may appear very simple, but it can become extremely challenging very quickly. Here's a video giving you my thoughts on the single-player side of the game (for those of us who have a hard time getting friends over).

http://youtu.be/K81IX5qE5JQ

In summary, here are the pros and cons of the game (some as ? because it varies on the person)

+ Simple controls. It makes it easy for anyone to pick up and play.
+ High skill ceiling. While moving, shooting, jumping, and dodging are the only controls, using them all in combination to navigate the diverse courses while shooting down foes is more than challenging to say the least.
+ Fluid gameplay. Everything responds exactly how you expect it to and when you expect it to.
+ Local Multiplayer is a blast. It's very competitive, and when you win, damn do you feel good.
+ Highly satisfying when you perform well. It takes a lot of skill to do this, and when you do, you know it.
+ A lot of enemy variety with different mechanics.

? Extremely challenging. You can make it so difficult, that you will never beat a level unless you perform near perfection. The one-hit-kill system makes this so.
? Even on normal, it doesn't hold your hand. You will die and fail multiple times before you learn the map's patterns and enemies so you can complete it. The time will differ greatly from person to person.
? The single player is decent. It's nowhere near as fun as the multiplayer, but that's to be expected of most games.

- No tutorial. The best I could find was something in the options menu that gives you hints, but you have to look for it. With something as difficult as this, anything that helps is greatly appreciated.
- IMO, I wish they used better quality sprites like the ones they have when you select your character. Just a small ding for this, though. Graphics only matter to a certain extent.
- This can be very frustrating in later levels. You just can't see everything that's coming at you, and when enemies fill the screen, it only makes it that much worse. Best thing to do is set it down and come back later, but that may be never depending on how bad it pissed you off.
- It's local multiplayer only. It cuts off a really good part of the game for those people who can't get people over to play. And I can't help but feel this game would've really benifited from having online servers so you can play multiplayer anytime.

In conclusion, get it for the multiplayer. You're gonna have a blast with it. If you have time to kill and like a challenge, then consider getting it for the single player. It's not bad for the price.

9391869.review:
Do you remember playing multiplayer games such as Goldeneye or Smash Bros. with friends for hours on end? TowerFall is that experience and more. Matches are fierce and exciting. They are the perfect length to allow players to rotate out without feeling too short. You’ll be cheering and yelling alongside everyone else as you wait for your turn.

TowerFall is a masterclass example of intentional game design. Nothing feels out of place or missing. The controls and pacing have been fine tuned to create the best possible experience.

While multiplayer is the main focus, and is amazing, there is a substantial amount of single player content. I’d like to focus on that in this review since everyone else is going to talk about multiplayer.

In quest mode you take on waves of enemies with a friend or by yourself. There’s one level for every tower with normal and hardcore difficulties, which I would rename to hardcore and insane. Waves and enemy movement are not random, they have been carefully designed to provide a varied and challenging experience. Even the simplest of enemies can be a huge obstacle with so much going on at once. The boss fights are epic too.

Perhaps the most challenging mode in TowerFall is trials mode. It’s like break-the-targets in Smash Bros. but way more intense. Each trial is like a puzzle -- figure out the optimal way to beat it -- then figure out how to pull it off. Gold times are set so someone moderately good at the game might have a chance with practice. Diamond times are even harder with most set to under a few seconds. It feels very satisfying when you pull it off. Each trial feels unique and like the game is trying to teach you something.

TowerFall is a beautiful game with an insane amount of visual polish. While its character and environment designs stand out, the details and animation are what puts it over the top. Everything from how the character moves to the environment details such as dripping water or crumbling skeletons.

This review is not complete without talking about the audio design. Each character has a unique set of sound effects. This not only gives them individual personalities but also lets you know what’s happening elsewhere on the screen. The soundtrack is also worthy of much praise. Each tower has a unique track that matches the visuals perfectly. It echos the gameplay both in tempo and mood and tells a story at the same time.

Multiplayer is what you buy the game for but single player is very good too. TowerFall is an amazing game and is worth both your time and money.

9347025.review:
As a game designer, I'm sad that I have to live in a world where my entire job and sustenance is based on my ability to convince people to buy and play my games when they could be playing Towerfall instead. I can't really capture everything that I love about it into concise statements; it's bigger than life, it brings people together. I've forged strong friendships over this game. Heck, people want to be my friend just because I have it. 

It doesn't matter who you are or what kind of games you like. It doesn't even matter if you've never liked a game before. You will have fun playing Towerfall.

And it looks awesome. And the soundtrack kicks ass. Oh, and the sounds? The way every archer has a different synthetic "voice" so I can tell who's shooting and who's killed even when my eyes are closed? The way the jester makes one of three possible jingle sounds when he crouches?? Ugh. Everything about this game, every detail big and small. It's so good.

Bring controllers.
